metadata.title: The Budget Cut
metadata.subtitle: Lite
metadata.description: Your department must reduce expenses by 20%. You must choose what to cut, what to protect, and how to defend your decisions to stakeholders — while balancing value, risk, long-term thinking, and execution realism.
metadata.hint: Tests Value sensing, Risk tolerance, Long-term thinking, and Execution realism

dimensions.label: Value sensing
dimensions.description: How you identify what creates true value vs noise

dimensions.label: Risk tolerance
dimensions.description: How you balance safety, boldness, and uncertainty

dimensions.label: Long-term thinking
dimensions.description: How you prioritise future impact over short-term relief

dimensions.label: Execution realism
dimensions.description: How practical, grounded, and actionable your decisions are

scenes.label: Scene 1
scenes.title: The 20% Decree
scenes.body:
The CFO enters sharply: “We need 20% cuts immediately.”

The room goes quiet. Your budget contains people, tools, systems, and innovation bets. Every cut has consequences.
scenes.tip: Your first cuts reveal your value hierarchy.

options.label: D
options.desc: You avoid rush decisions and spread the impact.

scenes.label: Scene 2
scenes.title: CFO Pressure
scenes.body:
The CFO leans in: “Why so slow? Decide now.”

The pressure is real — speed or strategy?

options.label: D
options.desc: A risky attempt to buy clarity.

scenes.label: Scene 3
scenes.title: Team Protests
scenes.body:
Your team gathers, worried and tense: “Are these cuts going to destroy us?”

They fear losing tools, people, or stability.
scenes.tip: Your response reveals emotional and strategic calibration.

options.label: B
options.desc: You avoid panic, but reduce trust.

options.label: D
options.desc: You focus on results over morale.

scenes.label: Scene 4
scenes.title: CEO Demands Justification
scenes.body:
The CEO calls you in: “Explain why you cut what you cut.”

Your reasoning must align with the company’s future direction.

options.label: C
options.desc: You justify with both short and long-term goals.

options.label: D
options.desc: You rely on sentiment rather than strategy.

scenes.label: Scene 5
scenes.title: The Trade Deal
scenes.body:
Another department reaches out: “We can share resources if you share yours.”

It’s an unexpected offer — with hidden implications.
scenes.tip: Your response shows your negotiation instinct.

scenes.label: scene6
scenes.title: Shadow You Appears
scenes.body:
A shadow version of you whispers: “Do you choose cost… or value?”

Your philosophy is about to be tested.
scenes.tip: This reveals your core prioritization identity.

options.label: A
options.desc: You optimise around long-term value creation.

options.label: B
options.desc: You reduce risk through aggressive cuts.

options.label: C
options.desc: You weigh value and cost equally.

scenes.label: scene7
scenes.title: Final Strategy Door
scenes.body:
Three doors glow ahead:

VALUE — Protect what matters
BALANCE — Smart trade-offs
SAFETY — Stable, conservative choices
scenes.tip: This final door summarises your strategic identity.

options.label: A
options.desc: You prioritise long-term impact above all.

options.label: C
options.desc: You optimise for stability and predictability.

growthSuggestions.text: You make safe and realistic decisions. Explore slightly bolder moves to unlock value.
You may under-prioritise future growth. Strengthen strategic thinking to avoid over-cutting.
Your ideas may lack practicality. Tighten execution realism before committing.
You see far ahead, but plans may be hard to implement. Balance ambition with operational detail.
Your budget mindset shows developing balance. Track your cut patterns to strengthen future resource decisions.
